title: Central Ideas & Details
subtitle: Reading & Writing Foundation
learning_objectives: The Core: Master identifying main ideas vs. supporting details
The Skill: Distinguish between what a passage is about vs. what it says
The Problem: Answer choices designed to confuse topic with main idea
Key Strategy: The 3-Phase MAIN Strategy for 100% provable main ideas

content.heading: The Main Quest
bullet_points: Decode the difference between topic and main idea
Apply the 3-Phase MAIN Strategy for certainty
Eliminate trap answers with surgical precision

content.heading: PHASE 1: Map the Territory
content.subtitle: Find What vs. Why

strategy_steps.title: Identify the TOPIC
strategy_steps.description: What is this passage discussing? (Usually a noun/noun phrase)
points: The topic answers: 'What is this about?'
Look for repeated concepts, not just repeated words
Topic is concrete: renewable energy, facial recognition, urban farming

strategy_steps.title: Find the ANGLE
strategy_steps.description: What specific aspect of the topic does the author focus on?
points: Not just 'renewable energy' but 'economic benefits of renewable energy'
Not just 'social media' but 'social media's impact on teen mental health'
The angle narrows the topic to what the author specifically addresses

example.text: Passage about urban vertical farming addressing food security challenges in cities.

breakdown.angle: How it solves food security challenges
breakdown.note: The passage isn't about vertical farming in general—it's specifically about its role in food security

content.key_insight: The topic is WHAT the passage discusses. The angle is WHICH ASPECT the author focuses on.

core_principle.title: Purpose Is King
core_principle.description: The main idea = Topic + Author's Purpose. Purpose answers WHY the author wrote this.

purpose_categories.signals: Should, must, need to, important that, essential, critical
purpose_categories.example: Author argues governments should increase renewable energy investment

purpose_categories.signals: How, why, what causes, the process, the mechanism
purpose_categories.example: Author explains how facial recognition works in the brain
Author describes the various functions of bioluminescence

purpose_categories.signals: Similarities, differences, in contrast, both, while
purpose_categories.example: Author analyzes differences between traditional and vertical farming

strategy_steps.title: Read the Opening & Closing
strategy_steps.description: Authors often state purpose explicitly at beginning or end
strategy_steps.example: Opening: 'The phenomenon of bioluminescence has fascinated scientists...' → Purpose: To explain/inform

strategy_steps.title: Check the Tone
strategy_steps.description: Is the author neutral, advocating, questioning, critiquing?
strategy_steps.example: Neutral tone → explain/inform. Advocating tone → argue/persuade

strategy_steps.title: Look for Purpose Signal Words
strategy_steps.example: 'Understanding flow has practical applications...' → Purpose: to explain applications

elements.reveal: The SAT never asks about random details. Main idea questions test whether you understand what the author is DOING, not just what they're SAYING. Purpose > topic.

content.heading: PHASE 3: Eliminate with Surgical Precision
content.subtitle: The 100% Rule: Find Why 3 Are Wrong, Prove 1 Is Perfect

core_principle.title: College Board's Trap Patterns
core_principle.description: Wrong answers follow predictable patterns. Learn these and you'll never fall for them again.

trap_types.description: Focuses on one paragraph or example, not the whole passage
trap_types.example: Passage about vertical farming → Wrong: 'Vertical farms use 95% less water'
trap_types.why_wrong: This is a supporting detail, not the main idea about food security

trap_types.description: So general it could apply to many passages
trap_types.example: Passage about facial recognition → Wrong: 'The brain processes information'
trap_types.why_wrong: Too vague—doesn't capture the specific focus on facial recognition

trap_types.description: States what the passage is about, but not the author's point
trap_types.example: Passage arguing for renewable energy → Wrong: 'The passage discusses renewable energy'
trap_types.why_wrong: This states the topic but misses the PURPOSE (to argue for investment)

trap_types.description: Correct topic but wrong author intent
trap_types.example: Passage explaining flow → Wrong: 'The passage argues flow is better than other states'
trap_types.why_wrong: Author explains flow, doesn't argue it's superior

trap_types.description: Introduces ideas not in the passage or twists what's there
trap_types.example: Passage on Curie's achievements → Wrong: 'Discrimination prevented Curie's success'
trap_types.why_wrong: Passage says she faced discrimination but ultimately succeeded

elimination_process.title: Check Coverage
elimination_process.question: Does this answer cover the WHOLE passage or just part?
elimination_process.action: Eliminate answers that focus on one paragraph/detail

elimination_process.title: Verify Purpose Match
elimination_process.question: Does this answer reflect the author's PURPOSE (argue, explain, describe)?
elimination_process.action: Eliminate answers with wrong purpose verbs

elimination_process.title: Test Specificity
elimination_process.question: Is this specific enough to be meaningful but broad enough to cover everything?
elimination_process.action: Eliminate too broad (vague) or too narrow (detail-focused) answers

elimination_process.title: Confirm 100% Accuracy
elimination_process.question: Can I point to evidence throughout the passage for this?
elimination_process.action: The correct answer should be supported by multiple parts of the passage

slides.title: Guided Practice: The Strategy in Action

content.heading: Let's Apply All 3 Phases Together
content.passage: The phenomenon of bioluminescence—the production of light by living organisms—has fascinated scientists for centuries. While most people associate this ability with fireflies, bioluminescence is actually most common in marine environments, where up to 90% of organisms in the deep ocean produce their own light. This biological lighting serves various purposes: some species use it to attract prey, others to communicate with potential mates, and still others to confuse or deter predators. Recent research has revealed that bioluminescence evolved independently at least 40 times throughout natural history, suggesting that the ability to produce light provides significant survival advantages. Scientists are now studying these natural light-producing mechanisms to develop new biotechnologies, including more efficient lighting systems and medical imaging techniques.
content.question: The main purpose of the passage is to:

walkthrough.question: What is the TOPIC?
walkthrough.reasoning: The passage repeatedly discusses bioluminescence throughout—in title, examples, functions, and applications

walkthrough.question: What is the ANGLE?
walkthrough.answer: The various functions and significance of bioluminescence
walkthrough.reasoning: The passage covers multiple aspects: where it occurs, what purposes it serves, evolutionary significance, and applications

walkthrough.question: What is the author's PURPOSE?
walkthrough.answer: To EXPLAIN/INFORM about bioluminescence's functions and importance
walkthrough.reasoning: Neutral, informative tone. No argument or advocacy. Uses explanatory language: 'serves various purposes,' 'revealed that,' 'suggesting that'

walkthrough.question: Now let's eliminate wrong answers using our trap patterns

options_analysis.text: explain why fireflies are the most well-known bioluminescent organisms
options_analysis.flaw: Fireflies mentioned briefly in one sentence. Passage isn't explaining WHY they're well-known—just noting most people associate bioluminescence with them before moving to the real focus (marine environments)

options_analysis.text: describe the various functions and significance of bioluminescence in nature
options_analysis.validation: ✓ Covers whole passage (functions: prey, communication, defense; significance: evolutionary advantages, biotech applications). ✓ Correct purpose (describe/explain). ✓ Right specificity level

options_analysis.text: argue that bioluminescence research should receive more funding
options_analysis.flaw: Author never argues for anything. No 'should,' 'must,' 'need to.' Passage explains what scientists are doing, doesn't advocate for more research

options_analysis.text: compare marine bioluminescence to terrestrial bioluminescence
options_analysis.flaw: Passage mentions marine vs. terrestrial briefly but doesn't compare them systematically. The focus is on functions and significance, not comparison

slides.title: Your Turn: Apply the MAIN Strategy

content.heading: Independent Practice
content.instructions: Use all 3 phases: Map Territory → Decode Purpose → Eliminate Traps
content.passage: Urban vertical farming represents a revolutionary approach to agriculture that could help address food security challenges in growing cities. Unlike traditional farming, vertical farms use stacked layers of crops in controlled indoor environments, allowing year-round production regardless of weather conditions. These facilities employ LED lighting systems, hydroponic or aeroponic growing methods, and precise climate control to optimize plant growth while using 95% less water than conventional farming. Although the initial setup costs are substantial, vertical farms can produce up to 390 times more food per square foot than traditional farms. As urban populations continue to expand and arable land becomes scarcer, vertical farming offers a sustainable solution that brings food production closer to consumers, reduces transportation costs, and minimizes environmental impact.
content.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the passage?
content.strategy_reminder: Phase 1: Topic = vertical farming. Angle = ? Purpose = argue/explain? Phase 2: Check tone and signal words. Phase 3: Eliminate using trap patterns.

options: Vertical farms use advanced LED lighting and hydroponic systems to grow crops indoors.
Traditional farming methods are becoming outdated due to climate change and urbanization.
Vertical farming offers an innovative solution to urban food security challenges through efficient, sustainable agriculture.
The initial costs of vertical farming are high, but the long-term benefits justify the investment.
content.explanation:
Let's apply Phase 3 elimination:

A: TOO NARROW trap—focuses on technical details (LED, hydroponics) from one part, misses the main point about food security solutions.

B: DISTORTION trap—passage doesn't argue traditional farming is 'becoming outdated.' It presents vertical farming as a solution to specific urban challenges.

C: ✓ CORRECT—Covers whole passage (Topic: vertical farming + Purpose: to present/explain it as a solution to food security). Matches the opening claim and final sentence.

D: TOO NARROW trap—costs mentioned in one sentence. Passage focus is food security solution, not cost-benefit analysis.

content.heading: Master These Traps—Never Fall for Them Again

rows: Focuses on one paragraph, one example, or specific data
Ask: Does this cover the WHOLE passage or just one part?
So general it could apply to many passages
Ask: Is this specific enough to distinguish THIS passage from others?
Says what passage is 'about' without the author's point
Ask: Does this include the author's PURPOSE, not just the subject?
Correct topic but wrong verb (argue vs. explain, etc.)
Ask: Does the verb match the author's actual intent?
Twists what the passage says or adds ideas not present
Ask: Can I point to specific evidence for every part of this?

content.expert_insight: The correct answer will feel almost boring—it simply, accurately states what the author is doing without drama or distortion.

content.heading: Central Ideas & Details Mastery
key_points: Phase 1: Map Territory—identify topic and angle (what specific aspect)
Phase 2: Decode Purpose—determine why author wrote this (argue, explain, describe, analyze)
Phase 3: Eliminate Traps—use the 5 trap patterns to eliminate 3 wrong answers
The 100% Rule: Correct answer covers whole passage, matches purpose, supported throughout
content.strategy_reminder: Remember MAIN: Map territory, Analyze purpose, Identify traps, Name the answer that's 100% provable
content.expert_insight: SAT Reading tests whether you understand what the author is DOING, not just what they're SAYING. Purpose > topic.

content.message: Outstanding! You've mastered the art of identifying main ideas with surgical precision.

slides.title: Mastery Check
slides.question:
The concept of 'flow'—a psychological state of complete immersion and focus—was first introduced by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi in the 1970s. When experiencing flow, individuals report losing track of time, feeling effortlessly concentrated, and performing at their peak ability. This state occurs when there's a perfect balance between the challenge level of a task and a person's skill level: too easy, and boredom sets in; too difficult, and anxiety takes over. Flow has been observed across diverse activities, from athletic performance to artistic creation to professional work. Understanding flow has practical applications for education, workplace productivity, and personal fulfillment. By designing activities that promote flow states, teachers can enhance student engagement, managers can improve employee satisfaction, and individuals can achieve greater happiness and accomplishment in their daily lives.

The passage primarily serves to:
options: define the concept of flow and explain its applications for improving human performance and satisfaction
argue that Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi's research on flow should be more widely recognized
compare flow states experienced in athletic activities versus artistic endeavors
demonstrate that achieving flow requires finding the perfect balance between challenge and skill
slides.explanation:
Phase 3 Elimination:

A: ✓ CORRECT—Topic: flow concept. Purpose: to define and explain applications. Covers whole passage (definition, characteristics, conditions, applications across domains).

B: WRONG PURPOSE trap—Author explains flow, doesn't argue researcher needs recognition. No 'should,' no advocacy.

C: WRONG STRUCTURE trap—Passage mentions athletics and arts as examples but doesn't compare them. Focus is on defining flow and explaining applications.

D: TOO NARROW trap—Balance of challenge/skill is ONE condition for flow (mentioned in middle), not the main idea of entire passage. Misses the applications focus in second half.

strategy_card.title: The MAIN Strategy Quick Reference

steps: Identify TOPIC: What is this about?
Check opening & closing for purpose clues
Identify purpose: argue, explain, describe, analyze
Verify with tone and signal words

strategy_card.the_100_rule: The correct answer covers the whole passage, matches the author's purpose, and is supported throughout. The other 3 have specific, identifiable flaws.

common_mistakes: Choosing detail-focused answers instead of passage-wide main ideas
Selecting correct topic but wrong purpose (e.g., 'explains' vs. 'argues')
Falling for answers that are too broad or too narrow
Missing the author's PURPOSE and only identifying the subject

trap_quick_reference.Too Narrow: Focus on one part/detail → Ask: Covers whole passage?
trap_quick_reference.Too Broad: Vague, generic claim → Ask: Specific to THIS passage?
trap_quick_reference.Topic Not Main: States subject without purpose → Ask: Includes WHY author wrote?
trap_quick_reference.Wrong Purpose: Wrong verb (argue/explain/etc.) → Ask: Matches author's intent?
trap_quick_reference.Distortion: Twists or adds ideas → Ask: All parts supported by text?

strategy_integration.key_innovation: 3-Phase MAIN Strategy: Map Territory → Analyze Purpose → Identify Traps
